We encourage you to have a look around the catalog first to see what we’re all about before posting your first thread. Topics typically posted here include:
>Outdoor recreational activities (Hiking, trail running, bushwhacking, camping, spelunking, geocaching, orienteering, expeditions, urban exploration, backpacking, etc.)
>Gardening, farming and related activities
>Hunting and fishing, and other activities involving the stalking or taking of game (including bird-watching)
>Outdoor survival, bushcraft, foraging, self-sustenance in nature, train-hopping, hoboism, etc.
>Outdoor destinations and exploration (specific trails, parks, regions, etc.)
>Water-related activities (boats, diving, etc.)
>Outdoor philosophy (conservation, Leave No Trace, protectionism, etc.)
>Outdoor building and living (cabins, huts, treehouses, etc.)
>Outdoor social activities and organizations (meet-ups, Scouts, NOLS, etc.)
>Gear related to any of the above topics

Most topics related to the outdoors are fine. Write properly, behave politely, encourage a respectful community, and most importantly, GO OUTSIDE!!

>>2491247
Sorry, I've been ignoring /out/ for a while.

First of all, let it dry for a week or so in a cool, dry place with the bark still on (removing the bark right away could cause the wood to dry too quickly and crack), then strip off all the bark and let it dry for another week or two. Trim it however you wish, but an oscillating multitool is fantastic for precisely trimming knobs/knots almost flush with the surface.

First of all, sand it down real good. I do this by hand with a sheet because it's the best way and not terribly labor-intensive. Use 80 grit, then 180 grit; grip the shaft pornographically with the hand holding the sandpaper, then rotate back and forth while working slowly down the entire length. Repeat as necessary; buff problem spots; spend time smoothing down the stumps of the knobs and knots you trimmed.

For the very first coat after sanding, use orange oil or some kind of cutting board oil to fill up the pores a bit. Let it soak in for a while, then wipe the staff dry.

Melt the beeswax ((in a double boiler, tea candle warmer, etc.), and apply a generous coat with a cotton cloth. Wait at least an hour for the wax to soak in and set, then buff it out, again with a cotton cloth. This is the most labor-intensive part, as you do fast circles with two fingers under the cotton over the entire surface.

Repeat the wax coating and buffing 5-6 times.

The super-shiny staves you see in stores have been sprayed with polyurethane. Absolute crap.

>any of you /out/ists taken the offgrid cabin pill yet? howd it go?
I've been off grid for 5 years but get called a larper whenever I post so kind of gave up contributing. I bought a cheap single bedroom cottage in rural NE Victoria (australia) because it was close to a dairy farm I was managing that was already on septic and tank water. Everything works. I have a normal kitchen and office and can blare music and play video games like any other person. All my power tools are corded but the inverter has no trouble powering a pressure washer or angle grinder. A few solar panels and an inverter was all it took to take it completely off grid. Having the rain water tank at ground level is the biggest drain on my power though, every time I turn a tap there's a 50W jet pump that goes brrrr and draws the same power as a microwave running on high. Keep your rain water at roof-gutter level instead of ground level to allow gravity to keep the water pressure up so you can at least shit and shower if the power goes out. My house looks like any other 1960's Australian fibro cottage but I take a working holiday every couple of years to Taree as a cattle drover and stay in pic-related.

I want to talk about how hard it is to be green, but it really isn't. I just gifted most of my shit to grateful friends when I was 28ish and have room to move now

>These are species with thin bark that aren't supposed to survive a wildfire. Same with red cedar
Are you sure... there are/were red cedars that are 1000s of years old, surely they can survive some fire (or you're wrong about fire disturbances being as common as you think). Red cedars live long enough that their tops break off and the tree regrows from a side growth, repeatedly, forming a "candelabra". The dead, broken trunks don't rot because red cedar is insanely rot resistant, which helps it thrive in the wet PNW.

>>2501425
I'm not saying to cut down every last tree, especially not old growth (at that point it is better to leave it as a forest). But the truth is that most forests today are second growth ecological deserts with little to no undergrowth aside from a couple ferns. It's just a bunch of crowded fast growing trees less than 30 years old without any of the deadfall and rotting wood that supports biodiversity.
It's impossible to create an old growth forest by planting trees, it's much easier to plant a grassland and let it naturally evolve into woodlands over time. But of course that takes time and in today's zoom zoom tik tok world it's easier to plant a bunch of saplings in a grid and look like you did something.

threads.sub: Fly fishing noob. Need advice. Want to get set up for under $100 or so.
threads.com: Oldfag here who’s been spinfishing since forever but I’m living in a fly fishing Mecca of sorts and I’ll be retiring soon and want to take up the hobby but not invest too much in tackle. Any decent combos to recommend?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2500272
I started with a cheap reel and cheap rod, both were 40$, while my buddy picked up a 200$ three piece.
Being truthfully honest, there is no difference in the quality or value between 80$ and 200$. So probably safe bet to just go cheap w/ a pre-dressed reel.

You'll have to probably pay another 20$-40$ for leader, line, flies, carry box, etc.

Fly fishing isn't my main thing, but its a nice change of pace to get small trout & blue gill (What i usually go for). So I wouldn't be too concerned about getting anything quality. Just important to go out, practice, learn, and try different flies.

I fly fish top water off a small boat on lakes & I haven't tried rivers yet. Will hopefully try that soon

I agree, by the way, that it's bare minimum of $300 to get started: a $40 Chinese reel, an $80 fly line, a $100ish rod, flies, nippers (not optional), leaders/leader material, backer, tippet spools.

In a small enough creek in the spring and summer you can free wade. You can also wade with muck boots or hip waders in small, cold creeks.

But good chest waders cost hundreds, minimum, double that with stockingfoots and good wading boots.

last_replies.name: Anonymous

>>2501267
yeah i'm just saying if you're literally clanging pennies together, the better tarps on aliexpress are a major step up from the hardware store.
i think the sweet spot are the low end cottage brands. everything that's under 200 bucks and not made of cuben fiber basically. dd being an example of one of them.
>What size is really needed for one person to make an enclosed tent shelter?
depends how big you are and what pitches you plan on doing
9 foot ridgeline is the ideal size IMO. the width depends on you and things like if you want to keep your gear inside or outside etc. i usually tell people 9x7ft or around there is what will feel ideal for most solo hikers.
i'm a really small mfer so i personally use a 9x5ft.
>square or rectangular?
if weight/packability is a concern rectangles usually come out on top. either is fine though.

if you want to fuck around with custom tarp sizes cheaply before buying a tarp, just make a diy polycryo tarp or a tyvek one. once you find the right size and buy your tarp, cut the diy tarp down into your ground sheet. you're pretty much out $0 if you don't already have a ground sheet and already own a roll of duct tape.
https://backpackinglight.com/forums/topic/how-to-make-a-polycryo-a-frame-tarp/
example instructions, just use normal duct tape for your demo/trial one.

last_replies.com:
>>2500913
the main gimmick behind arcteryx is the laminated construction. which makes them a lot lighter and more packable compared to something fully stitch constructed. its traded off in cost and shorter lifespan.
as you do more extreme things outdoors your priorities shift from how long your jacket lasts to how well does it perform the task. i'm not a fan of arcteryx but that's the mentality behind why milsurp is not suited for a lot of peoples' needs.
also despite your milsurp jacket being made of "gore-tex" and the fancy arcteryx one on the shelf also being made of "gore-tex", gore tex is more of a brand than a material, there's a wide range in quality it can be. a jacket made of shakedry is pretty incomparable to your typical milsurp goretex jacket.

Want to get into smoking pipes without spending too much cash?
Get a corncob pipe and a pouch of either Captain Black or Half and Half tobacco, available at most drugstores.
What you'll need: pipe, tobacco, lighter or matches, pipe cleaners, and either a regular old nail or a pipe tool (combination tamper, scoop, and small pick).

>>2501173
>'d you do a routine checkup or why did you climb the mast?
That was an equipment upgrade and installation of 2 microwave dishes on the tower. Also did a router replacement (ran out of ports on the old one) and rebuilt the DC distribution in the rack.
I climb and do rf engineering shit professionally. A lot of the sites I work in have that fallout/urbex vibe. Some sites are real nice and clean, but those are more the exception than the norm.
Pic related is the top of a coal mill. The silos the facility used to store coal in for the boilers was repurposed as a radio site since it offered good coverage to the entire facility. Behind me in this pic is 3 racks of radios/routers/combiners/duplexers/etc.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2501173
>How oft do you have issues with homeless and the like?
Once every year or two, a site I deal with gets broken into. Sometimes it's shitbags just being shitbags, wanting to get into something they're not supposed to and cause a little mayhem. Other times it's copper thieves (cables/wire, grounding busbars are a big target). Sometimes it's druggies/homeless/undesireables.
Every now and then there's the adventure-seekers who want to climb the tower "just because". I can't blame them too much for that, it's part of why I got into the job. But them doing so without training/equipment puts huge liability on site owners/operators, and there's the risk of damage to the equipment on the tower.

Nowadays, just about every site's got cameras and alarms on it. I know as soon as someone's on the site, even just wandering around looking at things.

This site's got a real creepy feel to it. There's a bunch of fed/gov equipment up here. Cables with tags on it that read "SECRET SERVICE".

Some of these sites are like a trip back in time. Cellular tech disrupted a lot of other wireless industries. Racks and racks of equipment for large businesses to acquire telemetry, sensor data, vehicle positions, etc all got replaced with little 3G/LTE radios riding on cell carrier's infrastructure. Cheaper to leave the vintage equipment on site and let it rot, to be "someone else's problem", than haul it down the mountain and dispose of it otherwise.

There is no reason why Iowa shouldn't be at the bottom. The only worthwhile /out/ there is hunting, and even that's not thar good. The entire state is just corn/onions farms and cow pastures. Sure, it's "the outdoors" and not all built up with roads and cities, but that doesn't make it not shit. The winds roll through at 20-30 mph regularly, often reaching 50 mph gusts in the wintertime. This does have the benefit of making it so the snow doesn't pile up, but this also means there's jack all to do in the winter. And practically the entire state is private property owned by ornery farmers who are well within their legal right to shoot you for trespassing and they WILL do it. Granted, all my time in Iowa was spent doing surveys for scummy pipeline companies using a weird unknown law that let me onto their land, so my presence wasn't exactly appreciated. Still, unless you're fantastic friends and a local, there really isn't anywhere to go except your own property. Wanna snowmobile or hunt? Pay the landowners or you don't. Fishing? There's a few lakes with mediocre catch. And God forbid you want to hike or camp.
You couldn't pay me a billion dollars to live in that godawful state.

Most people dying from hypothermia is not in the freezing winter, but casual unprepared hikers getting wet in the rain and it's only ~10c or so. They probably have a cotton t-shirt, cotton sweat shirt or hoodie, cotton pants/jeans, cotton socks, cotton underwear. They'll quickly cool down, start panic and possibly get lost or too far away from civilization.

In freezing temperatures cotton is alright because it doesn't really get wet.
There is tight woven cotton that is water resistant. Not sure how good it is.
Most outdoor cotton gear is mix with poly, 35-40% cotton, 60-65% poly. In my experience that will dry up fairly quickly.

In my experience, going fishing its a great way to start going /out/.
You dont need a lot of money to start doing it, you dont need to be very experienced since you can fish very close from a parking lot, and there Is a lot of tutorials in YouTube, also, you will learn what kind of clothes are good for being outside for long time, and what you need to bring (food, water, tools, etc)
Once you get confortable fishing during a whole day, you can start camping+fishing, to go one step further hiking+fishing+camping (at this point you can consider yourself a true /out/ist) then you can do camping+hiking only trips, and at this point you can start mountaineering. And It all starts with the humble zebco rod+reel combo.
Of course, I started fishing when I was 6.

Download the Alltrails app and look in your area, or google day hikes for your state.

If you enjoy hiking, look into longer trails and get into backpacking. It's just hiking with extra steps and cooler summits. But start small and get a cheap day bag with a water bladder and go for a hike.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2500269
>Do I need to go to school or have experience to do forestry?
No, but you'll be apply against people that do have those. I applied to be a Park Ranger and couldn't even get that.
>Do all the workers have to put out fires? Can you work only during certain seasons?
From what they told me in the interview, most of the work is firefighting. Year round work, at least in my case it was.
>Is it worth the pay if you have no experience (so they will pay you less)?
According to the interview, the state sets the salary for the position and experience/college doesn't matter. It also pays about the same as working at McDonalds or Walmart.
>Is it worth doing just to try if you don’t want an entire career out of it?
That's all I wanted to do, but I didn't get the job. The interview made it pretty appealing as a career though even with the shit pay, mostly all the government benefits and how quickly you can "finish your service" and retire.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2500269
>Do I need to go to school or have experience to do forestry?
What he said
>>2500284

>Do all the workers have to put out fires? Can you work only during certain seasons?
No, but you usually have to have your 64 hour class or whatever the fuck it is now. There are seasonal positions but you have to worry about getting a call back next season, and you'll probably be stringing Christmas lights or some bullshit in the off season.
>Is it worth the pay if you have no experience (so they will pay you less)?
No, not unless you do something moderately important and even then it's not great, but damn is it fun.
>Is it worth doing just to try if you don’t want an entire career out of it?
If you can get in, fuck yeah. What you do on the fire line will be your baseline work ethic for the rest of your life. A hand crew on the fire line is probably one of the hardest jobs out there. Best job I ever had.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2498298
The big kicker to a twig stove in my opinion is how dry your fuel is.
The first time I took it out I failed to get truly dry kindling while my tinder/emergency lighters failed on me, definate morale hit. The second time while taking my car, plenty of dry kindling and good fire starters I considered that I could probably maintain a solid burn with some damper wood but would need to reserve bone-dry kindling as a base for the next few fires.

I'd say take it with you if you're sure you can take/forage good dry wood, otherwise maybe have a backup if your loadout can manage it.

The stove itself is essential desu, we're doing a road trip of distilleries and peaks around Scotland for three weeks in January. We'll be operating out of a car so weight isn't an issue.
We did this a few years ago and didn't have a great time because it was so cold and wet, but we pushed through it (and we used a very expensive tent which was utter dogshit). I'm just seeing if some creature comforts can be added.
All hot tents in the UK seem to be DIY jobs of old ponchos for 1 person, or have a price comparable to the Savotta Hiwu. The Hiwu caught my attention because weather in Finland certainly is harsher than in Scotland so it'll definitely hold up, plus the sides have two angles so there's better usage of corner space, and there are some British retailers: a local store has 3 in stock (weirdly they aren't listed as a retailer on Savotta's website...). Plus it fits 4 people comfortably which is how many are coming.
I'd just buy the two halves, my friend already has a stove to use which is certainly tall enough (the stacking flue is like 4 metres if all parts are used and has a spark arrestor), and I'd just use tybek as a groundsheet.
